“On occasion, a grammatically singular noun that refers to a group of sorts (e.g., калык [kɑlək] ‘people’, кӱтӱ [kyty] ‘herd’, еш [jeʃ] ‘family’), or pair nouns/collective nouns [...], co-occur with plural forms of verbs. In these cases, singular verbal forms are however also possible, and recommended by prescriptive grammarians.”
There is no case agreement within noun phrases at all.
There is no case agreement within noun phrases at all.

It could however be reasoned that postpositions that encode oblique arguments have been subject to morphologization and that it is only description tradition and orthographic norms that prevent them from being considered case suffixed (EG 163-164).

“The gerunds in -мек(е) [-mek(e)] and -меш(ке) [-meʃ(ke)] take possessive suffixes; their agent, which can (but does not have to) differ from the agent of the superordinate (often finite) verb, can be marked by a preceding pronoun or noun. If the agent of the gerundial action is a noun, it can be in the nominative or the genitive. Inanimate nouns generally occur in the nominative, while animate nouns occur in either the nominative or genitive. When used with a genitive form, the gerund usually has a possessive suffix third person.” (EG 254) The same applies to participles (EG 261, 265, 266); the picture is more complicated with postpositions (EG 160) where the government depends on the individual postposition.
Differential object marking can be attested only in non-finite clauses (EG 70).

Compound past tenses I & II (formed by present-tense form followed by ‘to be’ in the third person singular, either in simple past I or II) are habitual (the distinction between them is evidential). Also, aspectual auxiliaries (light verbs) илаш ‘to live’ and шогалаш ‘to stand up’ can be coupled with a converb and give the resulting pairing a habitual value.

Numerous defivational suffixes, descending by their productivity: v-л [-l]: лӱмдаш [lymdɑʃ] ‘to name’ → лӱмдылаш [lymdəlɑʃ] ‘to call names’, -ешт [-eʃt]: колаш [kolɑʃ] ‘to hear’ → колышташ [koləʃtɑʃ] ‘to listen’, -кал [-kɑl]: ойыраш [ojərɑʃ] ‘to separate’ → ойыркалаш [ojərkɑlɑʃ] ‘to sort’, -ед [-ed]: пуаш [puɑʃ] ‘to give’ → пуэдаш [puedɑʃ] ‘to hand out’. Also auxiliary опташ ‘to place (several items)’.
Aspectual auxiliary (light verb) илаш [ilɑʃ] ‘to live’ is used.
Especially in combination with atelic verbs or verbal pairings, the verb тӱҥалаш [tyŋɑlɑʃ] ‘to begin’ is used as a future auxiliary.
Simple past tense 1 forms can, in a structure presumably borrowed from Russian, be used to denote something that is about to happen in the immediate future.

The usual way of expressing this is using the converb of prior action. Also simple past III & IV (distinction between them is evidential), formed by a simple past II form followed by a past-tense form (simple past I and II respectively) of the verb ‘to be’ in the third person singular, are “used to denote an action in the past that preceded another action, or was interrupted by it”.

The particle улмаш [ulmɑʃ] (‘to be’ in simple past II, 3SG) is placed after verbs in sentences in order to “to imply an uncertainty of sorts, or an inference, and in some cases also that an event was unexpected and surprising”, e.g. паша-ште лий-м-ем годым тудо мал-а улмаш [pɑʃɑ-ʃte lij-m-em godəm tudo mɑl-ɑ ulmɑʃ] (work-INE be(come)-PTCP.PASS-PX1SG when 3SG sleep-3SG be.PST2.3SG) 'While I was at work, it turned out s/he was sleeping'. However, there is no grammatical disctinction between evidential and mirative form.
Only periphrastic forms are used.
There is a necessitive infinitive with the ending -мыла/-мӹлӓ [-məlɑ/-mə̈læ], and the future-necessitive participle in -шашлык/-шӓшлык [-ʃɑʃlək/-ʃæʃlək].
The future-necessitive participle in -шаш [-ʃɑʃ], which prototypically denotes necessity, can in some cases be used in this function.

There is, however, a suffix -ан [-ɑn] that can be attached to participles (EG 253) to indicate that they denote possible states rather than real states, e.g. почмо [pot͡ɕmo] 'opened', почман [pot͡ɕmɑn] 'openable'.
Realized by a highly productive derivational suffix.
One of the prototypical usage situations for the dative, which unlike the dative in Turkic or Ob-Ugric languages is not used in a spatial sense.

The reflexive marker -алт [-ɑlt] can  be used to create impersonal clauses that lack actual impersonal/passive semantics but rather show that an action was carried out involuntarily (see EG 392). Morphologically the verb is then 3SG. Subject marking is not possible then.
Probably Russian influence.

Exclamative clauses and in sentences used to express a desire can have bare infinitive predicates (EG 255). In negation, the nominalization is used in negative existentical clauses to indicate emphatic negation (EG 379).
This typically happens in Mari (only) with causative verb forms. The verbs meaning ‘rain’, ‘snow’ , and ‘blow’ (wind) require a subject.
Copula is not needed, e.g. тудо пиалан [tudo piɑlɑn] (3SG happy) 's/he is happy'; it is, however, possible to use  one.
The element -ды- [-də- ~ -tə-] is contained in numerous non-finite forms.
Realized by a highly productive derivational suffix.
While the participle is historically complex (negation element + ending of passive participle), it is treated as a unit in modern language.

“The subject of a passive participle can also be indicated by a noun placed before the participle. As a tendency, inanimate nouns occur in the nominative, while animate nouns occur in the genitive, with the participle taking a matching possessive suffix.”
No agreement between modifiers and superordinate nouns in general; participles do not differ from this norm.
Works with all participles but the active participle.
The converb in -н, which overwhelmingly forms adverbial forms, forms a very small set of adjectives. This is not a productive process (EG 269).
The basic word order is SOV. There is no obvious deviation from the norm in the imperative, at least not on a regular basis.

“The negation verb and the connegative form are tied to one another tightly in Mari. It is unusual for other elements (e.g., adverbs, pronouns) to occupy the space between them and it is unusual for the word order to change – the connegative form by default follows the negation verb.”
“Non-finite verbal forms are not inflected for tense and mood, but maintain some verbal properties, for example the argument structure (i.e., they can still have objects)."

Adjectives do not agree with the noun in number in the predicateve position, e.g. нине сӱрет-влак сылне ул-ыт [nine syret-vlɑk səlne ul-ət] (these picture-PL beautiful be-PRS.3PL) 'these pictures are beautiful'.
Analytic formation is used.

“Genitive forms, especially of pronouns, can be used as nominals meaning ‘my one, mine’, ‘your one, yours’, ‘his/her own one, his/hers’, etc. In this case, they can be declined as nouns. Other suffixes, also case suffixes, can follow the genitive suffix.”
The morphologization of certain postpositions (e.g. дек ‘to’) is proceeding faster on demonstrative pronouns: туддек ‘to him/her’ (EG 136)
The nominative case is used on both occasions, e.g. пӧрт [pørt] 'house' кок пӧрт [kok pørt] 'two houses'.

The three postpositions - деке [deke] ‘to’ (EG 169-170), дене [dene] ‘with’ (EG 170-172), деч [det͡ɕ] ‘from’ (EG 172-174) - used similar to external local cases in Finnic languages could be said to be de-facto cases for which the morphologization is complete; it is only description tradition and orthography that justifies its classification as a postposition rather than a case suffix (EG 163-164).

NB! The so-called comitative case mentioned in Mari grammars and textbooks has a radically different function.

“The comparative case is used to express similarity, likeness and can usually be translated into English as ‘like something/someone’, ‘as something/someone’. The object/person with which a noun in the comparative is compared can be used in varying syntactic functions in the sentence: subject, object, etc.”.
The dative is used to mark benefactors.

It should be noted that inanimate nouns traditionally did not occur in the genitive at all; inanimate nouns serving as a modification do occur in the nominative (EG 61-68), e.g. Вена университет [Venɑ universitet] (Vienna.NOM university) University of Vienna’ (see www.mari-language.com).
“Like the possessive suffix third person singular […] this possessive suffix can beused as a determining element, though its usage is more typical of folklore texts” (OMJ 125).

The possessive suffix is used to indicate a rreference to something previously discussed or otherwise salient to the conversation. It is especially commonly used to refer to a subset of a larger whole that is salient.
The “degrees of freedom” depend on the case (OMJ 516), e.g. пӧрт-ем-лан [pørt-em-lɑn] (house-PX1SG-DAT) 'to my house', пӧрт-лан-ем [pørt-lɑn-em] (house-DAT-PX1SG) 'to my house'.
There are no indications which would show that Cx before Nx is possible.

The same word is used in both cases, e.g. шокшо игечe [ʃokʃo iget͡ɕe] 'hot weather' - шокшо вӱд [ʃokʃo vyd] ‘hot water’; йӱштӧ игечe [jyʃtø iget͡ɕe] ‘cold weather’ - йӱштӧ вӱд [jyʃtø vyd] ‘cold water’.

Geminate (long) consonants only occur at morpheme boundaries. Minimal pairs are possible: ныллымше [nəlːəmʃe] ‘fortieth’ (← ныл [nəl] ‘four’ + лу [lu] ‘ten’ + ORD), нылымше [nələmʃe] ‘fourth’ (← ныл [nəl] ‘four’ + ORD).
Reduced vowels are shorter than full vowels, but there is a clear qualitative difference between non-reduced and reduced vowels, so it cannot be reasoned that vowel length alone is distinctive.
No distinctive vowel length at all.
No distinctive vowel length at all; geminate consonants only at morpheme boundaries.
However, as final unstressed [e] is reduced, it could be argued that the qualitative difference of this vowel is critical to the phonological disctinction between these words.
In Meadow Mari, suffixes containing full vowels are stressed, but this is in line with the regular stress rules.
The last full vowel (i.e. anything but [ə] or unstressed/reduced final [e], [o], [ø]) is stressed: пеледыш [peˈledəʃ] ‘flower’, пеледеш [peleˈdeʃ] ‘blossoms’.
Syllable structure has no transparent effect on where stress falls.
The last full vowel (i.e. anything but [ə] or unstressed/reduced final [e], [o], [ø]) is stressed.
Only for labial vowels.
Further palato-velar distinction for labial vowels.
There is however a “mid unrounded central vowel, reduced vowel similarly to the English reduced vowel that is denoted in different ways (alone, lemon, heaven)”, e.g. пыл [pəl] ‘cloud’.
Fairly rare and the effect of a fairly recent loss of reduced vowels that did not happen in all varieties of Mari.
The palatal consonants [ʎ] and [ɲ] are frequently mislabelled as palatalized. Palatalized pronunciation under Russian influence and especially in Russian loan words does happen.
Only in Russian loan words among contemporary speakers.
Only in Russian loan words.

Historically as allophones of the fricatives /β/, /γ/, /δ/ after homorganic nasals, i.e.: [mb], [ŋg], [nd]. “The historical pronunciation of these sounds is encountered only rarely today: [β] has generally been replaced by [v]; /b/ is perceived as an independent phoneme; the sounds [γ] and [δ] are mainly realized as [g] and [d] in all positions.”

It is uncommon, but not excluded. There are some words of proto-Uralic origin that have an initial r. There are some varieties in which intial r is preceded by prothetic ə, however, presumably under Chuvash indluence.

“Historically, Mari had three voiced fricative phonemes: /β/, /γ/ and /δ/ […] The historical pronunciation of these sounds is encountered only rarely today: […] the sounds [γ] and [δ] are mainly realized as [g] and [d] in all positions.”
Only in Russian loan words.

“Historically, Mari had three voiced fricative phonemes: /β/, /γ/ and /δ/ […] The historical pronunciation of these sounds is encountered only rarely today: [β] has generally been replaced by [v]”.
Only in Russian loan words.

There is alternation between [t] and [d] (not marked in orthography; д is used regardless of pronunciation) that has been said to resembles consonant gradation or final consonant devoicing: кид [kit] ‘hand’, кит-лан [kit-lɑn] hand-PX1PL, кид-ем [kid-em] hand-PX1SG. However, the historical explanation here is that [d] was spirantized to [ð] between vowels, and was later replaced by [d] under Russian influence.
In attributive clauses the modifyer has no case/number marker.
Possessive suffixes can be added to a range of postpositions to show the person and number of an oblique argument.
